Description: Cytokines are potent immune regulators with the potential to proliferation, differentiation, and effector function of innate and adaptive immune cells.  Although studied for more than 30 years as potential therapeutics to drive anti-tumor immunity, clinical success of cytokine drugs has been hampered by their poor pharmacokinetics, pleiotropic effects, and common issues with systemic off-tumor toxicity. The field of cytokine therapeutics has been re-energized by recent efforts to focus the activity of cytokines on cell populations in the tumor microenvironment or on target circulating lymphocytes enriched in tumor-specific cells. This session will cover recent approaches in various stages of preclinical-to-clinical translation aiming to focus cytokine activity in tumors, localize cytokine activity to target tumor or immune cell populations, and increase both the safety and efficacy of cytokines as immunotherapy drugs.
SearchResultBody: ADT05. New Developments in Immunotherapy: Targeting and Localizing Cytokine Activity
Title: New Developments in Immunotherapy: Targeting and Localizing Cytokine Activity
